title: Canonical Coherence and Systematic Reading
objective: Check theological claims against the broader canon for coherence

required_passages.text: The law has a shadow of good things to come and cannot perfect worshipers by repeated sacrifices. Christ came to do the will of God and offered Himself once for all. By one offering He has perfected for all time those who are sanctified. Where forgiveness is complete, no further offering for sin remains.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson fifteen. We evaluate claims for coherence with the whole canon.

Listen to the passage. Hebrews 10:1-18. The law has a shadow of good things to come and cannot perfect worshipers by repeated sacrifices. Christ came to do the will of God and offered Himself once for all. By one offering He has perfected for all time those who are sanctified. Where forgiveness is complete, no further offering for sin remains. Now identify how the passage integrates earlier Scripture into one coherent canonical argument.
Canonical coherence means new claims should not contradict central teachings. The canon provides checks and balances for interpretation.
Compare your claim with parallel texts and key doctrinal passages. If tensions exist, revisit your exegesis and qualifications.
